answers.answer: Hi, understand your predicament. You have to tackle both the infection and the blood sugar levels, as raised sugar levels can increase the susceptibility to infections. Work with your doctor to reach euglycemic levels with medications and dietary control. And the best way to get to the bottom of your sinus issues is to see an ENT.  A good examination inside the nose with a camera might give the ENT more information as well as a CT scan of the sinuses.  If it is a chronic sinus infection, 4-6 weeks of antibiotics are pretty standard in addition to nasal steroid sprays, oral steroids, and salt water irrigations of the sinuses.  If this fails to solve the problem, sinus surgery is usually recommended. Regards.

question: I have been sick since July  It is now Sept 21.  I started with a sinus infection.  I then got a urinary tract infection.  Then some type of infection that had me coughing and short of breath.  I am on the fourth round of antibiotics since the middle of July.  I have type two diabetes.  My glucose levels rise sharply up to 296 and drop to 92.  I have been on steroids had steroid shots and prednisone dose pak.  I am not on any steroids now.  I am concerned about the sugar levels being so erratic.  I am still coughing up green mucous and sinuses are still bothering me.  I have postnasal drip also green and my sinuses are congested.  My teeth feel like they are going to fall out.  I am nauseated all day and fatigued.  My doctor put me on 12 units of insulin at bedtime.  I am also taking oral medication for diabetes.  I have fibromyalgia, rheumatoid arthritis, hypertension, and diabetes.  Any suggestions?This discussion is related to/posts/Respiratory-Disorders/Chronic-respiratory-infection4-months-and-no-diagnosis/show/284151.
